comment_by: Prof. M. Otto Zeee JCD ECS
comment_text:
So far it has been old school "throw-away rockets" with Rocket-Lab. 😋
Anyhow, I like their vision, innovative approach and spirit! Their style is a copy of SpaceX in a smaller scale!
The keyword is VERTICAL INTEGRATION, something made popular by Elon Musk and his companies organization structure!

$2,700 vs $22,200 per Kg is almost a ~1/9 ratio. So, Rocket Lab HAD TO DO SOMETHING to compete, as SpaceX could just launch 50 of their payloads for a very low price/Kg. The fact that this little rocket can deliver payloads of 150Kg vs 8000Kg of a F9 (GTO) and the launch cost makes a recovery mandatory to reach a ~1/9 cost-weight ratio. Beck is smart and knew this from the start to be his goal! The only logical recovery was an ARS to make the electron reusable...

Speaking of catching a Falcon 9, there actually is (was) a capable helicopter, Mi-12 (aka B-12 or the Homer), it holds a record of lifting 44200 kg up to 2255 meters. But, unfortunately, it's out of service now and stands in a museum near Moscow.
If they crack the passive re-usability of their rockets that will be a big deal.
But they could launch a human. A sub orbital joyride for one.
Could SpaceX maybe use a helicopter to recover fairings more reliably?

What if these rockets built a helicopter propeller into the top of the release section that could be powered by some remaining fuel, the blades could be flush with the sides of the rocket and then flip up as it's coming back down (once the parachute has slowed it enough)? Surely this would be a lot less weight than the extra fuel needed for the rocket-based landings, and you'd have a lot of landing stability with the combination of parachute and propellers at the tip for it to essentially hang from.
SpaceX air-recovery? Yes, but not the Falcon 9 booster, the fairings!

A German study was released a few months ago that looked into flyback booster stages that would be air-recoverable. In it the booster doesn't spend a lot of fuel to do a big boost back burn or landing on land or a barge or ship, but instead glides down range on small wings until it gets hooked in mid-air by a large aircraft like a 747 and then towed back.

The idea is that the technology for this already largely exists since that's what the U.S. or other militaries use to in-air refuel large aircraft.

NASA had a project (back around 2004) for a flying test-bed known as HyTex that was to be launched on a sounding rocket from Wallops and air captured by a helicopter in exactly the same mode as shown in this video. I worked on HyTex. It was part of NASA's Next Generation Launch Technology (NGLT) program. HyTex, along with NGLT was cancelled when NASA's Constellation (forerunner to SLS) was started. I'll have to do a video on it on my channel sometime. Do checkout my new YouTube channel Galactic Gregs  (by clicking on my icon) that I started this January! Love your channel Everyday Astronaut!

About SpaceX competing with Rocket Lab in small sats launches, I can think of four major points...
1. SpaceX price is definitely attractive, but if you are the satellite owner you also need to consider that being a ride share doesn't assure you are going to reach your target orbit. You need to be prepared to spend some delta-V of your own, hence you need an appropriate propulsion system (with all the engineering, testing, validation, assurance, ...): this quickly add costs up. Whereas Rocket Lab is going to deliver you to your target orbit (assuming they are launching only your satellite) and you only need to worry about the attitude control system (or at most a very low-power propulsion sytem)!!!
2. Also, equally important, with ride share there are definitely compromises in the maximization of objectives, for instance the correct time to launch: the priority is given to the "bigger" satellite owner in that specific launch... again, for small sat operators this could end up being more costly than launching with Rocket Lab. Of course, each satellite operator knows what they are doing and ultimately decide their best option for their objectives.
3. Even if SpaceX could lower the price even more, it is my opinion that this will not ends up costing too much to Rocket Lab, because of the latter's flexibility to reach the target orbit. Plus, satellite operators love the launches competitions!!! They need it!!! So, even if at some point in time SpaceX price is definitely more inviting than Rocket Lab, the latter will continue to receive support, thus having the chance to improve their hardware and operations.
4. Now that Rocket Lab is pursuing resuability, their costs may go down significantly... Tough, as stated in the presentation, it's a very hard work to actually reach it. A sincere good luck to Rocket Lab, hope to see you recover your first rocket asap!!!

Hey Tim, I'm curious, how practical do you think it would be, to use railguns, on the moon, and on one of Mars' moons, to send supplies to mars, and ship resources or other goods back. Launching a rocket in space with a railgun would let you send larger loads at higher speeds(as long as there's no people on board), and only need to carry enough fuel to decelerate on arrival. And could shorten the amount of time It would take to get supplies to mars in an emergency.

While I welcome any and all attempts at reusability, no matter how wacky or out there it may sound, I do wonder if this parachute catching will end up costing less than propulsive landing. Sure, development-wise it definitely won't cost as much as making a new rocket, but I wonder in the long term if you were to compare what they want to do, to theoretically creating a larger rocket that is also battery powered and also has the same payload, except that payload is in propulsive landing reusable mode, if that rocket would end up being cheaper. I know Beck keeps saying he doesn't want to make bigger rockets but it feels really all-or-nothing to me to say that a bigger rocket would immediately require a Falcon 9 sized vehicle. I don't see why a propulsive landing style vehicle can't be made just big enough to rival the Electron in reusable payload and nothing more. The only reason I think people argue to keep the rocket smaller is they can't fathom a larger rocket costing any less than a smaller one, but that's the whole point of reusability! The cost is all that matters, not the rocket's size.

Sure enough, a Falcon 9 fairing half weighs bang-on exactly the same as the spent electron first stage. They have similar heights, but the width is the killer, about 4 1/3 times the width.
Falcon 9 Fairing (each half)/spent Electron Rocket first stage

Mass: 950kg/950kg
Height: 13m/12.1m
Width: 5.2m/1.2m

Regarding the question of whether a helicopter could "catch" a Falcon 9 first stage:

The dry mass of the first stage is 22.2 tons. A CH-53E Super Stallion has a payload of only 14.5 tons. If we allow Russian helicopters, we can get closer with the Mi-26, at 20 tons.

So it might work, if you get two of them working together, similar to swallows carrying coconuts.
